titleStmt.title: An new enterlude of impacient pouerte newly imprynted. Foure men may well and easely playe it. Peace, Coll hassarde and Concience for one man. Haboundaunce and Mysrule for a nother man. Impacient pouerte, Prosperyte, [and] pouerte, for one. Enuy and the Somner for a nother man.
Impatient poverty.

titleStmt.title: An new enterlude of impacient pouerte newly imprynted. Foure men may well and easely playe it. Peace, Coll hassarde and Concience for one man. Haboundaunce and Mysrule for a nother man. Impacient pouerte, Prosperyte, [and] pouerte, for one. Enuy and the Somner for a nother man.
Impatient poverty.

notesStmt.note: Printer's name and publication date conjectured by STC.
The only known copy lacks all after sig.D, presumably E² , since this edition agrees page for page with STC 14112.5.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2012-08 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2012-09 Ali JakobsonText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: An new enterlude of Impacient pouerte newly Imprynted.
¶Foure men may well and eaſely playe it.

list.item: Peace. Collhaſſarde and Concience for one man.
Haboundaunce and Myſrule for a nother man.
Impacient pouerte, Proſperyte, & pouerte, for one.
Enuy and the Somner for a nother man.

lg.l: THe puyſaunt prynce and innocent moſt pure
which hūbly deſcēded from ye ſete ſēpiternall
Illumyne his beames of grace to euery creature
To withſtand the conflycte of our enemyes mortall
The deuyl, the worlde, & the fleſh, theſe thre in ſpecial
whiche ſetteth deuyſion betwene ye ſoule & the body
Inlike wiſe enuy ſetteth debat betwene party & partye
I ſpeake for this cauſe, dayly ye may ſe
How that by enuy and malyce, many be deſtroyed
Which if they had lyued in peace wt pacient humilite
Ryches and proſperyte with them had ben emploied
For there as is peace, no man is annoyed
For by peace men growe to great rycheſſe
And by peace men lyue in great quyetneſſe
I am named peace, which enuye doeth expell
Enuye with me ſhall neuer reſt
For enuy is one of the paynes of hell
When that he ſoiourneth in a mans breſt
Lyke the burnyng Fenix in her owne neſt
Though ſhe can none other hurte ne greue
yet ſhe dooth not ceaſe her ſelfe to myſcheue

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: A ſyr here was a longe predycacion
Me thought ye ſayd in your communication
To euery man peace was moſte behoued.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: For ſoth and ſo ſayd I.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: That ſhalbe proued contrary by and by
For by peace muche people are vndone

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: What people are tho.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: The armurer, the fletcher, and the bower
Maryners, Gonners, and the poore ſowdyer
Yea and alſo many another artyfycer
Whiche I do not reherſe by name

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: I ſaye the vnyuerſall people doth beſt obtayne
where as peace is euer abydyng

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt ſo god me helpe and halydome
For then were ſurgyons cleane vndone
Of them that wyll fyght and breake apate
They gete good lyuyng both early and late
And what ſayeſt thou by men of lawe
Theyr lyuyng were not worth a ſtrawe
And euery man ſhould lyue in peace.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: That is not for the commons encreaſe
For by peace they profyte in many a thinge
Peace ſetteth amyte betwene kyng & kynge
In tyme of peace marchauntes haue their courſe
To paſſe and repaſſe

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt knaue by the maſſe
For vnder colour of peace much ſuttelte hath bene wroughte
And ſhips are taken ye marchaūtes dere haue bought
Was that for their promocion
Nay in tyme of warre
Suche a knaue durſt not ſtere
By ye maſſe were it not for ſhame yt ſhoulde bere me a blow

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Holde thy handes thou lewde felowe
Thou art of euyll dyſpoſycion
thus agaynſt peace to repugne
The whiche from heauen deſcended downe
to brynge man out of captyuyte

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: A horton why doeſt thou lye
When were thou in heauen tell me by and by
Howe cameſt thou downe with a ladder or a rope

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: yt were no ſynne to hange the by the throte
Thy wordes be enuyous, not grounded on charite.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Syr one thyng I praye you tell me.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: What is that

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Haue ye any wyfe or no

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Why aſke ye ſo

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Bycauſe ye ſaye peace is moſte expedyent
yf your wyfe made you cockolde you beyng preſent
What woulde ye do

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Geue her ſuche punyſhement as longeth therto

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: A fal • e flatteryng horſouloo
Nowe thou ſayeſt agaynſt thyne owne declaration
Yf thou fyght where is then peace become

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: I breake not peace with doing due correction
For correction ſhould be done charytably
Iraſcemini et nolite peccare

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: I ſhall mete that at omnium quare
Pace ſhould forgeue and not be reuenged
Hence horſon by our lady of wolpit
I ſha • l rappe thee one the pate

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Go hence wretche thou make bate
yt were almes to ſet the in newgate
Howe maiſter conſtable come nere
Here is a wretche without reaſon
Take and put hym in pryſon
With as many yrons as he may beare

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: By our lady I wyll come no nere
A conſtable quod ha, nay that wyll I not abyde
For I am lothe to go ſhorter tyde
yet longe horſon for all thy pryde
I ſhall mete with thee another daye
When one of vs two ſhall goo a knaue a waye

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: O thou wretche thou ought to remorde
That ſo tarre arte exyled from charyte
Lo he thynketh not, howe mekely his maker & Lorde
Suffered reprefe and dyed vpon a tree
Geuynge vs example that with humylyte
Euery man ſhould folowe his trace
That in heauen wyll clayme a place

sp.speaker: ¶Impacient pouerte.
sp.l: Kepe kepe for coxs face.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Why art thou ſo out of pacience

sp.speaker: impacyent po.
sp.l: A knaue would haue reſted me I owe hym but .xl pence
He ſhall abyde by goddes dere bleſt.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Take hede my frende thus ſayeth the texte
In lytle medlyng ſtandeth great reſt
Therfore paye thy duetye well and honeſtly
With fewe wordes diſcretely
Another tyme ye ſhall be the better truſte

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: That wyl I neuer do whyle I lyue let him do hys beſt
I had leuer laye all my good to pledge
To gete a wryte of pryueldge
So may I gy by his noſe at large
Spyte of his tethe who ſo euer ſay nay

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: This is but a wilfull mynde if thou wilt not paye
Thy very duety, whiche can not be denade
Geuing of thy wryte and expence in the lawe
Wyll coſt more then thy duty, this well I knawe
Thy dette therewith can not be payde
yt is only a deferryng of the payment.

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: yet the knaue ſhall not haue his entent.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt pay by rightfull iudgement
For the lawe is indifferent to euery perſon

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: I ſe thou holdeſt on his opynion
yet I ſet not by you both a ryſſhe
And I mete the knaue I ſhall hewe his fleſſhe
Helpe hym thou olde churle and thou can

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: I ſe thou art an euyll dyſpoſed man
I vtterly forſake thy condycion

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: Mary auaunt long precious horſon
I ſet not by the nor hym, I make God auowe
I am as good a man as thou for all thy good
Let it be tryed by māhode, and therto I geue the my gloue

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Alſo to warryours I do reproue
For peace loueth not to fyght

sp.speaker: impacyent po.
sp.l: No olde foole, thou haſt thy myght
For in age is nought els but cowardyſe

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: youth with his courage lyght
Nor ſtrenght with multytude I do ye plight
Are not onely the cauſe of victory

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: No good ſyr, what then.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Grace and good gouernaunce of man
For with good diſcreſion they began
That were the great wynners of victory

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: The victory is gotten by diſcretion
I praye you ſyr ſhewe me this leſſon
How to come to rycheſſe, for that is all my care
For I am euer in great neceſſite
Meate and drynke with me is ſcarſyte
No man wyll truſt me of a peny
And alſo my clothes are but bare
Good ſyr what ſay you therin.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: I holde it punyſhement for thy ſynne
Shew me what is thy name

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: I am named Impacient pouerte

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: For ſoth that may well be
Thou art ſo full of wrath and enuy
In thee can growe no grace
But yf thou wylt forſake ſenſualyte
And be gouerned by reaſon, as I ſhall enduce thee
Thou ſhalt come to rycheſſe, within ſhorte ſpace

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: Shew me that now in this place
And therto I wyll agre

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Thou muſt loue thy neyghboure with charite
Do vnto hym, no maner of dyſeaſe
Loke howe thou would he dyd to thee
Do to hym no worſe in no degree
And then thou ſhalt our lorde pleaſe.

sp.speaker: impacy▪
sp.l: Shall I loue hym that loueth not me?
Thoſe that trouble & rebuke me ſhamfully
That wyll I neuer do whyle I lyue.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Thou muſt charitably all fautes forgeue
Wwat ſoeuer any man to thee ſaye
Let as thou hardeſt it not, turne thyne care awaye
Thou • halt pleaſe god, yf thou ſo do.

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: Nay by god there hoo
What is he in all this place
That wyll do as this man ſayde
Shewe me or I go
yf a man do you a great offence
Wyll ye kepe your pacience
Naye be god not ſo
I put caſe I breake your head
Wyll ye ſuffre that in very dede.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: to ſuffer for chriſtes ſake I ſhal haue mede

sp.speaker: impacy
sp.l: That ſhall I knowe by goddes breade.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Holde thy hande and kepe pacyence
thinke what chriſte ſuffered for our offence
He was beatē ſcourged, & ſpite on wt violēce
And ſuffered death for our ſake
yet he toke it paciently
He forgaue his death, & praied for his enmys
Pater dimite illis, his ſaying was truely
An exam 〈◊〉 vs to take
to be meke in harte: beati pauperes ſpiritu
Shall Chriſte ſaye full euen.
Et venite benediciti: come my bleſſed chyldren
To the kyngdome of heauen.

sp.speaker: impacy▪
sp.l: Syr I thanke you, for your ghoſtly inſtruction
Vnto your ſaying, I can make no delayaunce
I put me vnder your gouernacion
And for my myſdedes, I take greate repentaunce

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Then to my ſayinge, take good remembraunce
Exercyſe yourſelfe in vertue, from this tyme hence
And vnto peace euermore be obedyent
Syt before euery ſharpe word, a ſhilde of ſuffraunce
And when tyme is of your concupiſſaunce

sp.speaker: impacy.
sp.l: Then pacyfye it with benygne reſyſtaunce
Ser gramercy, yt ye haue brought me to this eſtate
By your aduertiſmēt I am willing to liue in chriſtes law
There as I haue offended him both early & late
I ſerued hym not for loue nor for awe
Therfore nowe ryght well I knowe
That pouerte and myſery that I my lyfe in leade
yt is but only punyſhement for my myſdeade

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Nowe or we any further procede
Holde this veſture and put it on thee
From henceforth thou ſhalt be called proſperytie

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: I thanke god and you I am in felicite

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Now vnto you I ſhall here ſhewe
Of ſuche thynges as ye ſhall eſchewe
Fyrſt your ſoule loke that ye kepe cleane
Beware of myſrule in any wyſe
Playe not at caylles, cardes nor dyſe
Alſo from miſwomen, for by them miſchefe may ryſe
As it doeth often, thys dayly is ſene
Haunte no tauernes, nor ſytte not vp late
Let no haſſardes nor riotours, wt you be checke mat
For then wyll enuy come, and make debate
The whiche ſhall cauſe great troble
Be plentyfull of ſuche as god hath ſent
Vnto ye poore people geue with good intēte
For euery peny that is ſo ſpent
God wyll ſende the double.
Take hede and do as I haue ſayde

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: Syr therwith I holde me well apayde
As ye haue commaunded me it ſhall be done

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Then let vs departe for a ſeaſon
plyenede I wyll be your protection. Exiūt ambo

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Ioye and ſolace be in this hall
Is there no man here that knoweth me at all
I am beloued both with great and ſmall
Haboundaunce is my name
I haue all thynges as me lyſt
Meate drynke, and cloth of the beſt
Golde and ſyluer, full is euery cheſt
In fayth I wyll not layne
I thynke ye knowe not my wayes
Howe I gette goodes nowe a dayes
By a propre meane
Thynke you that I woulde
Lende eyther ſyluer or golde
That daye ſhall not be ſene
But I wyll lende them ware
That ſhal be both badde and deare
Not worth the money he ſhall pay
And yf he can no ſuerte get
Of my ware he getteth ryght nought
Without a good pledge he laye
Then wyll I for myne auayle
He ſhall make a byll of ſayle
To me full bought, and ſolde
yf the daye be exſpyred and paſte
Then wyll I holde it faſte
He ſhall not haue it though he would
this crafte I haue longe vſed
And ſome men do not yet refuſe it
this is openly knowne
What is he in all this towne
that wyll lende without ſynguler commodſt
Shoulde I tende without a profyte
Nay than I holde nought worth my wytte.

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: All this ye ſaye, is agaynſt conſcience

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Conſcience quod a, nay then ſhal we neuer thryue
For I knowe hym not alyue
By conſcience that commeth to ſubſtaunce
I haue all maner of marchaundy
I ſell for longe dayes to them that are nedy
And for the payment I haue good ſuertye
Bounde in ſtatute marchaunce
Becauſe I maye forbeare
I ſell my ware ſo deare
I make fourty of twenty in halfe a yeare
Other men do ſo as well as I.

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Euen ſynne, vary ſhame mary fye
Theſe goodes are gotten vntrewely
Many a man is vndone therby
To take this ware to deare

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: They ſeke to me both farre and neare
Me thynke it is a good dede
To helpe a man at his nede
Yet I haue other meanes
Wherby to gette great gaynes
I thynke ye knowe not that

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: I no God wote

sp.speaker: Haboſt.
sp.l: No ye are but an ydyote
I ſolde a man as muche ware, as came to .xl. pondue
And in an oblygacion, I had hym bounde
To pay me at a certayne daye
And whan the bargayne was made playne
Myne owne ſeruaunt, bought the ſame ware againe
For the thyrde penny it coſte, ye wote what I meane
But was not this a wyſe waye?

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt repent it another daye
I charge the as farre as I maye
Suche falſe wayes neuer begynne

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Wherfore this is no ſynne
yt is playne byeng and ſellyng
Lawfull it is for a man to wynne
Els ryche ſhall he neuer be.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Wynnyng to be hadde, with due ſuffycience
In trewe byeng and ſellyng, is not to diſcommende
But for thy falſe vſuri, thou art curſed in ye ſentence
I praye God geue thee grace for to amende.

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Is euery man accurſed, that doeth bye and ſell
Then ſhall no man with marchaundyſe mell
Howe ſhall the worlde then be vpholde

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Nay ſyr, amyſſe ye do vnderſtande me
All thoſe that occupy falſe vſurye
And tranſgreſſeth the lawes of God by iniquitie
All ſuche are accurſed I you tolde
As for byeng and ſellyng, nedes muſt be
And God commaunded to lende to thē that are nedy
So it be not to their iniurye
For luker to theym ſolde.

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Howe ſhoulde I ſell, ſhewe me your wayes

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: ye may not ſell the dearer for dayes
yf ye do, it is contrarye to Goddes lawes

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: It is vſed in oure Countrey

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: yt is the more pytie
One ſuche is able to deſtroye a Cytye
And God ſhewe not his great mercy
All ſuche are dampned by his equite

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: God forfende that ſhould be
Howe ſhall men do that be of great reputacion
Whiche kepe theyr goodes on this ſame faſhyon
By vſury, dyſceyte and by extorcion
I do ſo my ſelfe, wherfore ſhoulde I lye

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Thou mayſt be the more ſorye

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: It is ſo nowe, what remedy

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Doo make reſtytucion

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: What call ye reſtytucion?

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Reſtore ſuche goodes as ye haue gotten
wrongfully by oppreſſion.
Then ſhall I haue lyttle in my poſſeſſion
I wyll make God amendes, another waye
I wyll faſte and I wyll praye
And I wyll geue almes euery daye
That I haue done amyſſe, I am ſory therfore

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: This is not ſufficient, thou muſt reſtore
Quia non dimittitur peccatum
Niſi reſtituatur ablatum
ye muſt reſtore to them, ye haue offended vnto

sp.speaker: haboū.
sp.l: Then I ſhall ſhewe you what I ſhall doo
I wyll put it in my Teſtamente
That myne executours ſhall paye and content
For wyle I lyue I wyll not haue my good ſpente
For yf I do I am but ſpylte

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Make amendes man for thy gylte
Rather ſpyll thy body then thy ſoule

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Men of ſubſtaunce ar a ſhamed to fall

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: That cauſeth them to reſt in their ſynne

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: yet euer with thy ſtrongeſt parte renneth the ball

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: yeſterday thou canſt not agayne call
when thou art dead ye gate of mercy is ſhut yu cannot come in

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Then let hym ſtande without

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: So of thy ſoule thou haſt no doute

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: When thou ſeeſt my ſoule torne ſet on a cloute
yf falſhode, vſury, and extorcion ſhould not route
Thouſandes in this realme ſhould be put out
The thyrde parte ſhould not byde by ſaynt Paule

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: yet often falſhode hath a greate fall
An example by kyng Achab with this ſothe
Deſyred the vyneyarde of that poore man Naboth
By counſell of Iezabell that kynges wyfe
Bycauſe he would not ſell his poſſeſſion
Of two falſe witneſſes he was peached of hye treaſō
And through the mouth of a falſe queſt it rane
which cauſed the poore man to leſe both lande & lyfe
After that of goddes owne byddyng
Came Helas the prophete to Achab the kyng
Saying he ſhoulde haue euyll endyng
And ſo he had, for by the waye as he rode
He fell and brake his necke, where dogges lapped his blode
this exāple to al vſurers & opp̄ſſours as thinketh me cōtrary
Shul cauſe them of god ſore a dred to be.

sp.speaker: haboun.
sp.l: Syr ye preache very holyly, but your dedes be oftē cōtrary
ye be ſo acquaynted with couetouſe and ſymony
That maketh vs to take the ſame waye

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: So euery euyll diſpoſed parſone doth ſaye
The fraylte of man doeth often offende
then call for grace, and ſhortly amende
Therfore I counſell thee to pretende
to repente and be ſory for thy myſdede

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: yet thus I wyll my lyfe lede
For of your ſaying I take no hede
ye wyll mucker vp both golde and treaſure
ye haue ryches without meaſure
And of the fleſhe ye haue your pleaſure
ye can find no wayes to amēd your ſelfe I you inſure
Therfore rebuke not me for my ſynne ne good
God be with you, you ſhall not rule me

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: O dule wytte plunged by ignoraunce
Regardyng nothyng by ghoſtly inſtruction
Setting more his mynde on worldly ſubſtaunce
Then to the euerlaſtyng lyfe that is to come
God wyll ſtryke when he lyſt, ye know not how ſone
therfore to euery man this counſell I geue
To be ſory of your ſynne, & do penaunce while ye liue
¶Here cometh enuye runnyng in
laughyng, & ſaith to conſcience.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Nowe in faith I would ye had be there

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Where ſhould I haue be.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: A better ſporte ye neuer ſe.

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Where at laughe ye ſo faſte

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: He to go and ſhe after.
And within a whyle he cought her
He toke of here an incroke
And chopte her on the hele with his fote
Anone be whypte her on the backe
A horſone quod ſhe, playeſt thou me that
And with her hele ſhe gaue hym a ſ • at
That he was fayne to go backe agayne

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Good felowe thou arte to blame
Suche wordes to haue no good thou can.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: I ſayde it to make you ſporte and game
I crye you mercy, I was to blame
I ſe ye are ſome vertuous man

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Shortely hence that waye thou came
For here thou ſhalt not be

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Good Lorde ſome ſuccour thou ſend me
That I be no not out caſte

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: What is thy name, ſhortly ſhewe me

sp.speaker: Enuye
sp.l: I dare not ſyr, by Chriſt Ieſu
Except ye kepe it pryuely.

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Feare not ſay on hardely

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Syr my ryght name is charytie
Sometyme beloued I was with the ſpiritualtie
But nowe couetouſe & ſimony doth them ſo auaūce
That good inſtitucion is turned to other ordinaunce
And bonum exemplum, is put to ſuche hinderaunce
That there I dare not apeare

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Symony is nowe in the ſpiritualtye
Bonus paſtor ouium, therto wyll ſee
Therfore me thynke this is a lye
In holy Churche ſymony can not abyde

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: He goth in a cloke he can not be eſpyed
And couetouſe ſo craftely doeth prouyde
that bonus paſtor ouiū, is blind & wil not ſee

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: That ye ſpeake is vpon enuy
Therfore I thinke ye be not Charytie
For charitie alwaye wyll ſaye the beſte

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Amonges them can I haue no reſte

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Howe do ye with the temporaltie

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: There is pryde, ſlowth and lechery
Which putteth me from that place

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Then be ye with the communaltie

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: They deſpyſe me vtterely
One of them loue no another
The ſyſter can not loue the brother
Ne the chylde the father ne mother
There I dare not ſhowe my face.

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: This is to me a ſtraunge caſe
What heare ye by conſcience.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Spiritual & tēporal ſet againſt him maruaylouſly
Marchaūtes, men of law & artyfycers of euery degre
They wyll hange hym and they hym eſpye
Such exclemacion goeth through this realme round

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Why what faute haue they founde
with hym ſo to do

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: His wytte is nought, they ſay alſo
Euery man putteth his wyll therto
To banyſhe hym for euer.

sp.speaker: Conſci
sp.l: I knowe well it is not as ye ſaye
For I am conſcience ye hye iudge of the lawe

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Be ye conſcience, alas that euer I this day ſawe
yf ye be taken, ye ſhalbe hanged and drawe
For they haue vtterly put you downe
And ſet couetyſe in your rowme
Subtylte the ſcrybe his owne coſyn

sp.speaker: Conſci
sp.l: And falſhed the ſomner, for the courtes promocion.

sp.speaker: Enuye
sp.l: I maruayle wherfore this was done
When riches came before you that muche wyl pay
There he had lyued in ſynne many a day
ye ſhould for mony lette hym go quyte a waye
And put hym to no ſhame
Let pouerte do penaunce for a lyttle offence
He is not able to promote you of .xx. pence
Then ſhould ye haue kept your reſydence
And gotten your ſelfe a good name.

sp.speaker: Conſc
sp.l: Who ſo doeth they are to blame
In myſorderyng them in ſuche wyſe

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: y wis coſyn I ſhewe you as now is ye guyſe
For by couetyſe muche people doeth vp ryſe
whiche is againſt both you and me

sp.speaker: Conſcy.
sp.l: Charyte I praye you ſhewe what remedy
In this matter for me may be founde

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Shortly get you to wyldernes, or ſome other regiō
For they wyll hange you vp at the Tyborne
If they fynde you in this place
And I muſte departe alſo

sp.speaker: Conſci
sp.l: This is to me muche ſorowe and wo
I wyll go into ſome farre countre
Fare well gentyll coſyn charyte

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: I ſhall praye for you, praye ye forme
This is an heauy departyng E • plorat
I can in no wyſe forbeare wepyng
yet keſſe me or ye go
For ſorowe my harte wyll breke in two
Is he gone, then haue at laughyng
Aſyr is not this a ioly game
That conſcience doeth not knowe my name
Enuy in fayth I am the ſame
what nedeth me for to lye
I hate conſcient, peace loue and reſte
Debate and ſtryfe that loue I beſte
Accordyng to my properte
when a man loueth well his wyfe
I brynge theym at debate and ſtryfe
This is ſene daylye
Alſo betwene ſyſter and brother
There ſhall no neyghbour loue another
where I dwell bye
And nowe I tell you playne
Of one man I haue dyſdayne
Proſperyte men do hym call
He is nye of my blood
And he to haue ſo muche worldly good
That greueth me worſt of all

sp.speaker: proſpe
sp.l: Ieſus that is both ſtedfaſt and ſtable
Euer perſeueraunt and neuer mutable
He ſaue this congreacion.

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: welcome pouerte by coxs paſſion
Ho we haue ye done this many a daye

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: I thanke god as well as any man may
ye call me wrong my name ia proſperyte

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Proſperyte with an euyll happe
Howe the deuyll fortuneſt that
I knewe the impacient pouertie

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Whatſoeur I was let that matter pas
And take me as I am.

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: I crye you mercy I was to blame
To call you by your olde name
yet all theſe people thynke ye are the ſame
Impacient pouertie as I ſayd before

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Auaunt I tell the, I am a gentylman bore
If I here the reporte ſuche wordes anymore
Thou ſhalt be punyſhed lyke a knaue.

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: A knaue quod, a cors paſſion
I am your owne coſyn
And nye of your conſanguynyte.

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Thou and I are not of one affinyte.

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: If I were a ryche man, ye would not ſaye ſo by me
ye wold then ſaye I were your next kynſmā on lyue

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: I ſaye go hence and make no more ſtryfe
I ſet not by ſuche a pore haſkarde

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Syr do not you knowe my name

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: I knowe the not by ſaynt Iame.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Charyte in fayth I am the ſame
what nedeth me for to lye
I am your coſen and ſo wyll I dye
ye may be glad ſuche a kynſman to haue

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Shall we haue more a do yet thou knaue
I charge the neuer knowe me for thy kynne

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: I praye you a worde or I go

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Saye on ſhortly then haue I do

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Syr, I haue of golde thre hundreth pounde
In a bagge faſte y bounde
At home loked in my cheſte
I purpoſe to go to Ieruſalem
ye ſhall kepe it tyll I come agayne
I putte you beſt in truſte.

sp.speaker: proſpe
sp.l: Coſyn I would fayne do the beſte
Becauſe ye are nere of my bloode

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: what, are ye nowe in that moode
Nowe I am your kynſman becauſe of my good
Before of me he had dyſdayne

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: As fore that I was to blame
I knew you not, be not angrye
ye are welcome to me coſyn charytie

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Then all theſe matters let be
I come hyther with you to dwell
ye muſt haue moſeruntes I do you tell
Suche as were neceſſare for your perſon

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: I am content after your prouyſion
In euery thyng let it be done
As ye thynke moſte expedient

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Syr I ſhall do myne entent
To gett you ſeruauntes mo

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: I prraye you hertely it may be ſo
A lytle ſeaſon I wyll from you go
To ſolace me with ſome recreacion Exit

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: He that ſytteth aboue the mone
Euermore be in your protection
Aha here is a ſporte for a Lorde
That proſperytie and I be well at accorde
I ſhall bryng his thryft vnder the borde
I truſte within ſhort ſpace
For it greueth my harte ryght ſore
He hath ſo muche treaſure in ſtore
And I haue neuer the more
I muſt fynde ſome proper ſhyfte
That from his good he may be lyfte
To bryng hym to miſrule I holde it beſte
For he can ſone bryng it to paſſe Here myſrule ſyngeth without commyng in
How what rutterkī haue we her
I would he were our ſubchauntere
Becauſe he can ſo well ſynge
Feytes bone ſhere pour lamour de aſynt Iohn

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: Mon • uer iocunde is ſet on a mery pynne
By my trouthe I am diſpoſed to reuelyng

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: So me thynketh by your commyng in
What myſrule where haſt thou bene many yeres
By my trouth euen amonges my peres

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: By my trouth euen amonges my peres
I came now ſtragiht from the ſtewes
From lytle prety I one
Lorde that ſhe is a prety one

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Holde thy peace let that alone
Harke a worde or twayne to the
I dwell nowe with proſperitie
whiche hath muche worldly treaſure
If thou can contryue in thy thought
Howe that he may be brought to nought
In all this worlde I deſyre no more.

sp.speaker: miſrule.
sp.l: Tuſhe take no thought therfore
I con prouyde for that in the beſt wyſe

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Then let me heare thy deuyce

sp.speaker: miſrule.
sp.l: I wyll brynge hym to claſſhe, cardes and dyſe
And to propre trulles that be wanton and nyce
which wyll not be kept at a ſmall pryce
Howe thynkeſt thou, wyll not this do well.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: yes but harken in counſell
Thou muſt chaunge thy name

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: I wyll ſaye I hyt myrth

sp.speaker: Enuye
sp.l: And I wyll ſaye theſame
Peace whyſt I ſe hym come

sp.speaker: Proſpe
sp.l: God ſaue all this honorable company

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Syr you be welcome by our bleſſed 〈◊〉
I haue thought for you full longe
Here is gentylman, I praye you for my ſake
Say he is welcōe & into your ſeruice hī take
For great courteſy he can

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: Syr you be welcome, geue me your hande
And ſhew me what is your name

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: Syr my name is myrth
Beloued with lordes and ladyes of byrth
At euery tryumphe I am them with
They can me not ones forbeare

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: And ye had ſought this thouſand yeare
Suche another ye ſhall not fynde
wherfore I counſell you in my mynde
Let hym dwell with you for one yer.

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: At your requeſt I am content
Suche a prete man for me were expedient
And of his counſell fayne woulde I here.

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Syr ye muſt ſynge and daunce & make good chere
I would ye had ſome propre wenche
That were yonge and luſty at a pynche
Here hele were not ſo brode as an ynche
She would quycken your courage

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Peace hath forbydden me ye outrage

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: He would ſet you at dotage
Becauſe he is olde and nature is paſte
He would nowe euer man ſhould faſte
yf ye do ſo ye do but waſte
And vnto you no mede

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: A ſtrawe for hym, ye haue no nede
Of hym to ſtande in awe or drede
A meryer lyfe nowe maye ye lede
Therfore be at your owne lybertye

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: By my trouthe I may ſay to thee
Syte I to hym dyd aſſent
Had I neuer mery day
But lyued in feare and drede alwaye
Nothyng to myne entente
Another whyle I wyll me ſporte
Synge and daunce to my comforte.

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: And amonge mery company do reſort
For that ſhall length your lyfe

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Spare neyther mayde ne wyfe
Take both and they come in your waye

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Of with this lewde araye
yt becometh you nought by this daye

sp.speaker: proſper
sp.l: By my trouth euen as you ſaye
ye mary nowe am I well apayde
Me thynketh I am properly arayde
yf I had a propre trul ſhe ſhould be aſaid
In the worſhype of the new yere

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Ruſſhe vp mutton for beefe is deare
Haue and reuell and chaunce:

sp.speaker: miſrule.
sp.l: Now let vs both ſynge and daunce
Wyll ye haue a frenche rounde

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: And thou ſhalt ſe me bounce aboue the grounde
Hey with reuell daſhe

sp.speaker: Peace
sp.l: What proſperite is it come hereto

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: What deuyll of hell haſt thou to do
Shall I not make mery when me lyſte.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: yet I ſaye beware of had I wyſt

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Hens ye knaue or els thou ſhalt lycke my fyſt
I trowe thy head wolde haue ſome knockes

sp.speaker: Proſpe
sp.l: Go ſet hym in a payre of ſtockes
That I hym no more ſe.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: yet man I ſaye remember thee
And thynke what I to the haue ſayde.
Eſcheue euermore theſe ryatours company
And be ruled by reaſon as I thee badde
Put from the theſe two parſons by whō thou art lad
Enuy & myſrule with theyr ſinful & great abuſyon
Which if thou wylt not forſake, will be thy confuiſon

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: Auaunt lorden, and take this for a cancluſion
Theſe men fro me thou ſhalt not ſeperate
Go out of my ſyght or by coxs paſſion
I ſhall laye the faſte in newegate

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: It is better to forſake them betyme then to late
This knaue would haue a broken pate

sp.speaker: miſrule.
sp.l: Let me alone by goddes bread
This ſame ſworde ſhall ſtryke of his head.
I praye you hence that ye were rydde

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: Shortly haue hym out of my ſyght
A lytle whyle geue me reſpyte

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: And take hede what I do ſaye
Remembre in what condicion thou was
when I fyrſt mette the in this place
Full ſymple in poore araye
Nowe by the grace of god and counſel of me
Thou art come to great proſperyte
And ſo mayſt contynue vntyll thou dye
yf thou wyſely take hede
Let not ſenſualyte lede the brydell
Be occupyed in vertue, and be not ydell
The better ſhalt thou procede
Theſe wreches wyll thy goodes ſpende and waſte
then ſhalt thou be taken for an out caſte
And mocked and ſcorned with moſte and leeſt
Then wyll no man the helpe at nede

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: A ſyr euyll mote thou ſpede
That ſo can rede his deſtanye.

sp.speaker: miſrule
sp.l: Wyll ye ſuffre this knaue in your companye
Then god be with you I wyll forſake you

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Go hence or in fayth I ſhall make you.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Then to almyghty god I betake you

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Let me come to that bragg • r
I ſhall thruſt him thorowe the ars with my dagger
(And here the face Peace out of the place)
Howe ſaye ye, was not this a good face
To dryue a knaue out of the place

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: In fayth thou made hym runne a pace
Thou loked as thou hade bene madde

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: Nowe by my trouth my harte is gladde
Some mynſtrell nowe I woulde we hadde
To reuell and daunce, for by ſaynt • hadde
I am ſo lyght me thinke I flee.

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: ye mary ſo ſhoulde it be
For nowe I holde you wyſe.
Syr and ye wyll do by myne aduyſe

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Let vs go ſtrayght to the floure delyce
There ſhall ye fynde a man wyl playe at dyce
with you for an hundreth pounde.

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: What man is he

sp.speaker: miſrule
sp.l: Colehaſſarde came late from beyond ye ſee
Ragged and torne in a garded cote
And in his purſe neuer a grote
And now he goeth lyke a lorde

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: I praye thee tell at one worde
Is he a gentylman bore.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Tuſſhe take no thought therfore
For be he gentylman knaue or boye
yf he come here with a tryfle, or a toye
He can no money lacke

sp.speaker: Proſpe.
sp.l: Now by the bread that god brake
I thynke longe tyll I hym ſe
Myrth go before and ordayne a good dyſſhe
One of fleſſhe another of fyſſhe

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Nay let all be fleſſhe
A yonge pullet tender and neſſhe
That neuer came on broche, haue with ye or thou go

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: What ſhall I haue?

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Foure quarters of a knaue
Roſted vpon a ſpytte Exit myſrule.

sp.speaker: Proſpe
sp.l: Now by my trouth and Colhaſſard wyll ſytte
I wyll play as l • nge as an hundreth pound wyll laſte

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: And ye wyll play an hundreth pound at a caſt
He wyll kepe you playe.

sp.speaker: proſpe.
sp.l: Then let vs go our waye
I ſyt on thornes tyll I come there

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: That ſhall make your thryfte full bare

sp.speaker: proſperi
sp.l: What wyll it do

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: I ſaye we ſhall haue good chere
When we come there. Exūt ambo.

lg.l: When phebus draweth into the occydentall
And obſerued with clowdes myſty and darke
Then trees, herbes, and graſſe, by courſe naturall
want their chefe cōfort, thus ſayth many a clacke
And lykewyſe that man in his warke
Is deſtytute of reaſon, folowyng ſenſuall operacion
The laſt tyme I was in this place
Proſperite vnto myſrule put his hole confydence
He regarded not my counſell, he lacked grace
which in tyme coming ſhal turne him to incōueniēce
with haſſarders, and ryotters, he kepeth reſydence
At claſ he and cardes with al vnthryfty game
whyche in contynuaunce ſhall bryng hym to ſhame
To hym yet I wyll reſorte
yf he be brought in pouertie
I ſhall do hym all the comforte
And all the helpe that lyeth in me
I wyll neuer reſte tyll I hym ſe
But ſeke about from place, to place
And bryng hym to ſome better grace. Exit

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: Colhaſſarde arte then there
Horeſon knaue wylt thou not appere
By my trouth I had went to haue founde hym here
I holde hym gone ſome other waye
And where is enuy I can not hym eſpye
I trowe he is with proſperytie
Proſperyte, nay, I may call hym folyſſhe pouertie
As wyſe as a drake
I haue brought hym to dyce, cardes, and claſ he
And euer on his ſyde ranne the loſſe
That he is not worthe a hendfull of moſſe
Neyther hath not a hole brat to his backe

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Paſſion of god is it come to that
This tydynges maketh my harte gladde

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: In fayth he hath neyther golde, ſyluer, ne plate
Colhaſſarde and I be both at one
He promyſed me to haue halfe the game
that euery thyng ſhall be deuyded in twayne
He to haue the one halfe and I the other

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Then let vs be partoners as brother and brother

sp.speaker: myſru.
sp.l: I can not ſaye, tyll colhaſſarde come
then ſhall we knowe, both all and ſome

sp.speaker: Colhaſſarde.
sp.l: Here is a bagge of golde ſo rounde
Here in is two thouſand pounde
Of proſperyte me it wonne
what man wt me is able to make comparyſō
Nowe ſhall I take a marchauntes place
to occupy I truſte within ſhorte ſpace
To be in credence with Englyſhmen
And when I am ſo well betruſte
I may borowe ſo muche as me luſte
A ſubtyll crafte then fynde I muſte
to conuaye vnder coloure lyke fre men

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Herke this knaue ſo proude and ſtoute
that hadde not to his arſe a hole cloute
whē he came to this land, & now hath brought about
To compare with a ſtate

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Nowe muſte I haue halfe money and halfe plate

sp.speaker: Calhaſ.
sp.l: Nay by god there thou ſpake to late
None thereof from me ſhall ſcape
then had I lyued to longe

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Thou promyſed me, when thou began
Halfe thy wynnyng I ſhall haue

sp.speaker: Colhaſ.
sp.l: Holde thy peace lewde knaue
knoweſt thou to whome thou doeſt ſpeake

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: A horeſon thy head ſhall I breake

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: For the paſſion of god ſobre your mode
I feare ſhedyng of knaues bloude
¶Here they fight & rune al out of the place
And then entreth proſperiti poorely & ſaieth

sp.speaker: pouerte
sp.l: O Ieſu what maye this meane
My goodes are ſpent and waſted away
Alſo my men are from me clene
I ſe them not this ſeuen nyghtes daye
As longe as I myght ſpende and paye
They helde me vp with falſe dyſſimulacion
And nowe they forſake me in my moſte trybulacion

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Come for cox • bones, why tary ye ſo longe

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: In faith I come as as faſte as I can
I am ſo angry I wot not what to do
That yonder knaue ſcaped from me ſo

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: What knaue is this I holde hym ſome ſpye

sp.speaker: pouerty
sp.l: I am your mayſter, knowe ye not me

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Thou art come late out of marſhall ſee

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Me thynke his hayre groweth thorowe his hode

sp.speaker: pouerte
sp.l: Alas Collhaſſarde hath wonne all my good
And lefte me neuer a groate

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Mary ſo me thynke, ye haue chaunged your coate
But nowe ye haue one vauntage.
what is that.

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: your executours ſhall not ſtryue for your goode another daye pouerte
Nor theues ſhall not robbe you goyng by the waye
Thus ye ſhall ſtande out of doute

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Hens ragged knaue or thou ſhalt beare me a clout
His clothes ſmell all of the ſmoke

sp.speaker: Enuye
sp.l: Nowe by ſaynt Hewe that holy biſſhoppe
This matter is well brought to paſſe
He is nowe a knaue as he was
Fyrſt a knaue, and then a man
And nowe he is a knaue agayne

sp.speaker: pouerte.
sp.l: Why ſaye ye ſo ye be to blame
I am your maiſter proſperytie

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Auaunt lorell and euyll to the
Get the out of this company
Begynneſt thou nowe to make compariſō

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: Let hym be your vnder page
Geue hym meate and drynke and no wage
Go bruſhe his gowne & make clene his ſhone

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Well knaue canſt thou no courteyſye

sp.speaker: enuye.
sp.l: He hath ſuche a dyſeaſe in his knee
He can not chaunge a man a groate
It is not as ye wene

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: Come and ſe my ſhone made clene

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: By my fayth he ſhall wype myne

sp.speaker: myſrule
sp.l: This knaue is not mete for me
yt greueth my harte when I hym ſe
I wyll go hence and leue you twayne
For enuy thou mayſt with pouertie rayne. Exit

sp.speaker: Enuye.
sp.l: Nay I had rether he were ſlayne.
I am gone as ſone as ye Exit

sp.speaker: pouerte
sp.l: Abyde ſtyll with me gentyll charyte
O to whome ſhould I ſewe, to whom ſhulde I plete
O mortall worme wrapped all in wo
As a man all mortyfyed, and maſed in my wytte
I a captyfe in captyuite, lo fortune is my foo
I am in endleſſe ſorowe, alas what ſhall I do
theſe captiues thorow their coūcel & falſe imaginaciō
Haue brought me to nought yt was of gret reputaciō
Wo worth the tyme that I them knew
I may well ſyghe, and ſaye alas
For now I fynde theſe wodes full trewe
That peace ſhewed me here in this place
I regarded not his councell, I lacked grace
wherfore nedy pouerty on me doth blow his horne
That euery man and womā doth laugh me to ſcorne
Example to all yonge men when they take in hande
To occupye in the world for your behofe
Loke wyſely before, and alſo vnderſtande
Euil company deſtroyeth man, on me ye ſe the profe
Make a ſure foundacyon, or ye ſet vp the rofe
Of a good & vertuous begīnīg cometh a good endīg
And euermore beware of vnmeſurable ſpending.

sp.speaker: Some.
sp.l: I aſſyte you in our court to appeare

sp.speaker: pouerte
sp.l: I pray you tell me wherfore

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: ye be a great ſlaunderer and full of enuy

sp.speaker: pouerty
sp.l: There wyll no man ſay ſo but you

sp.speaker: Some.
sp.l: what wylt thou geue me and thou ſhalt go quyte

sp.speaker: pouerte
sp.l: By my trouth I haue not one myte

sp.speaker: Some
sp.l: Then open penaunce and thou art lyke

sp.speaker: pouerte
sp.l: By my trouth I ſclander no man

sp.speaker: Some.
sp.l: Then come & ſcuſe thy ſelfe as well as thou can

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: What man is he that can me dyſmay
For I optayne all thyng at my wyll
Or dare any thyng agaynſt me ſaye
what ſoeuer I do be it good or yll
For yf he do he were better be ſtyll
I ſhall hym punyſhe be it ryght or wronge
For with in my purſe, I can both ſaue and hang
To repunge agaynſt me he were better be ſtyl
I haue a propre trull for my paſtaunce
In my chamber I her kepe, both nyght and daye
My neyghbours therwith, taketh great greuaunce
yet I kepe her ſtyll whoſoeuer ſay nay
Howe be it there is one a poore caytyfe I heare ſaye
Hath me accuſed in the courte ſpyritual
And it coſt me a .C.li. punyſhe hym I ſhal

sp.speaker: Some.
sp.l: Open ſynne muſt haue open penaunce
God ſpede my mayſter haboundaunce

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: what knaue art thou wt a very miſchaūce
That cometh in ſo homely.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Syr I praye you be not angry
I am an offycer of the ſpiritualte
There is vpon you a great ſcleaunder
ye kepe another mans wife in your chambre
And lyue in great aduoutrye

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: what wretches doeth ſo ſaye by me

sp.speaker: Some.
sp.l: it is openly knowen euery where
Before my maiſter I charge you to appere
Vpon a boke there ſhall ye ſwere
whether it be ſo or no

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: what is the beſte for me to do
Rather than I to the courte wyll go
I had • euer ſpende twenty pounde

sp.speaker: Some
sp.l: Syr if ſuche a waye may be founde
To excuſe you, what wyll ye then ſaye

sp.speaker: Haboū.
sp.l: Now therof hartely I the praye

sp.speaker: Some.
sp.l: ye ſhall come home to my maiſters place
And ſaye that ye be put vp of malyce
Thruſt mony in his hande a pace
And ſo ſhall ye go quyte awaye

sp.speaker: Haboun
sp.l: For thy counſell gramercy: holde here is .xl pence.

sp.speaker: Some
sp.l: Come on ſir I wil do my dyligence. exiunt ambo

div.stage: Here entreth the ſumner againe, and pouerte foloweth him with a candell in his hande doyng penaunce about the place. And then ſayeth the ſomner.

sp.l: Rowme ſyrs auoydaunce
